The judge could not be more over it with Alex Jones and his lawyers after these recent antics.
Judge to Alex Jones' lawyer: "So Mr. Jones was too ignorant to know that he was lying? Is that your defense?"

Judge says she's not bringing the jury today, but reminds Alex Jones he's under oath when he comes back tomorrow and to stop bringing up asides, like his torn larynx.

"If you don't know something, you don't say it. If you're asked about your opinion, you can give your opinion."

Alex Jones: "I believed everything I said was true."

Judge: "You believe everything you say is true but it isn't. That is what we're doing here... Things must actually be true when you say them."

Judge to Alex Jones:

"You are already under oath to tell the truth. You have already violated that oath twice today. It seems absurd to tell you again that you need to tell the truth while you testify, but here I am: You need to tell the truth while you testify."

She also agrees Watson posed a danger to the safety and well-being of another, per NFL policy. 

And yet leads with this:
‚ÄúIt is undisputed that Mr. Watson‚Äôs conduct does not fall into the category of violent conduct that would require the minimum 6-game suspension.‚Äù

Read through Sue Robinson's findings in the Deshaun Watson case & I'm more confused than ever.

She determines the NFL proved what Watson did was sexual assault by the its own definition. 

She then acknowledges that the NFL‚Äôs policy on violent conduct includes sexual assault.

The last time we heard from Deshaun Watson was on June 14 when he said: "Like I said, I never assaulted anyone. I never harassed anyone. I never disrespected anyone. I never forced anyone to do anything."

At what point has he expressed any public remorse? https://t.co/l9HZ8nvKtL

The Haslam family claims to defer to Judge Sue Robinson but also says they know Watson is remorseful. Robinson considered Watson's "lack of expressed remorse" to be an aggravating factor in his case. https://t.co/4dx7W34Qkm

My TLDL version of the 16-page report: Robinson agreed with the NFL on everything except for suspension length.
Robinson wrote that the NFL met its burden to prove Watson violated the personal conduct policy in "various ways," including that he "engaged in sexual assault."

Judge Sue L. Robinson noted "a lack of remorse" as an aggravating factor in her disciplinary decision. She cited Watson's status as a first-time offender and his work in the community as a mitigating factor.

Several notable lines from the 16-page report on Deshaun Watson:
- Although this is the most significant punishment ever imposed on an NFL player for allegations of 
non-violent sexual conduct, Mr. Watson‚Äôs pattern of conduct is more egregious than any before reviewed by the NFL

Again, Robinson relies on the NFL to set its policy. She finds Watson's conduct did pose a genuine danger to the safety and well-being of another person as laid out broadly by the NFL https://t.co/4pY9GdwbOn

We need to be clear. The judge found Watson guilty of egregious behavior. She also imposed unprecedented rules because she clearly fears him reoffending. How you decide those two things and then come up with only six games. It is hard to understand

Judge Robinson was bound by the personal conduct policy and in her role to rely on the NFL's definition of sexual assault, which was ‚Äúunwanted sexual contact with another person.‚Äù She found Watson engaged in sexual assault (as defined by the NFL) against the four
therapists. https://t.co/2Ss2xhG9zN
